content.formatted_body:
Here's an example:

// Each item has a few pipelined actions that take time indicated by the number. So the first item does 3 operations each taking 500ms
function* gen() {
  yield* [[500, 500, 500, 'a'], [500, 500, 500, 'b'], [10, 10, 10, 'c'], [10, 10, 10, 'd'], [10, 10, 10, 'e'], [10, 10, 10, 'f']];
}
for await (const i of gen.map(async item => {
	await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, item.shift()));
  return item;
}).map(async item => {
	await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, item.shift()));
  return item;
}).map(async item => {
	await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, item.shift()));
  return item;
})) {
  // This will after summation of all the times in each array.
  console.log(item.shift());
}

content.body: Handled in-order one must wait 300ms to see the first result. All the operations are handled sequentially taking a total 300 * 2 + 30 * 4 = 720ms. An out of order first come with a task limit of 5 for each step (assume these are network or single worker thread delays) would take 300ms. Even a task limit of 3 would take 300ms. in that example.
